All contributions of money, or provisions, will be accepted for the benefit of the wounded.
jy 7--2t*

Daily Union Prayer, Meetings, under the auspices of the Young Men's Christian Association, will be held every Evening this week, at 6 o'clock, in the First Baptist Church, (Rev. Dr. Burrows's) corner 12th and Broad sts.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The officers and members of Dabney's Artillery wish to return their sincere thanks to F. Stearns, Esq., for his uniform kindness, not only to the officers and men of their company, but to all other soldiers quartered near his residence.
Long life and prosperity to Mr. S., is the wish of
jy 7--1t* Dabney's heavy Artillery.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--camp Winder Hospital.
I, Moses Whelchel, am at First Ward from the flag of the third division, and can cure any kind of a Sore Leg, Piles, or Dyspepsia.
No cure no pay. Or any Venerate complaint, of any age. Medicine taken according to direction.
Try me.

div3.p:
--The subscriber has removed his office to No. 87 Main street, over Strider's Skirt Manufactory, where he will be pleased to see all who may desire his services.
Best references given.
M. A. Blankman,
Surgeon Dentist,

div3.head: Reading for the wounded.
div3.p:
--The friends of the wounded soldiers can get at Randolph Bookstore, 121 Main street, a small supply of readable Magazines, without price. Families who have an over stock of light literature would do a good thing by sending them in for distribution.

div3.head: Boarding.
div3.p:
--Two or three small families can be accommodated with Board and Rooms in a private family.
The rooms are not furnished.--Terms reasonable.
Applicants will please give their names, and state, where they can be seen.--Apply by note to "M. H." Dispatch office.

The Concern of Augustine J. Smith &Co.
is this day dissolved by gained comment,

div3.head: From the South-side.
div3.p:
--Gentlemen from below counted eighty vessels of all kinds at and below Berkeley yesterday.
The usual wagon train, a great number of tents, and supplies for 30,000 men, were congregated there.
There was heavy cannonading yesterday, back of Berkeley, from 12 to half past 1. Dense columns of smoke were seen arising.
Subsequently the gunboat Monitor and another passed up above City Point, shelling the woods frequently as they progressed.

The Tribune, of the 28th ult., has been received it states that the killed, wounded, and missing at the fight near Charleston was 688. Gen. Benham was placed under arrest for making the attack.
He and his staff have reached New York.
The fight caused a decline in stocks.
Petersburg, July 6.--The Yankees have buried over 500 of their dead at Shirley, and left over 100 wounded, who fell into our hands.
Our pickets now occupy Shirley.

Nine more prisoners have been brought to Petersburg.
They say that McClellan was in a strong position at Berkeley, that he has been reinforced by Shields's division, has 80 to 100,000 men, and will give battle.
Balloons were sent up yesterday and to-day.
The wagon train is still visible, and the tents of the enemy dot the country for miles.
A member of Sickles's brigade says that out of 5,000 men not more than 500 are left.

div3.head: War movements in Mississippi and Arkansas.
div3.p: --A special dispatch to the Advertiser, dated Grenada, 3d, says:

cit.q:
Four thousand Federals advancing South, seven miles from Holly Springs, were attacked yesterday by Jackson's and Pierson's cavalry, fifteen hundred strong.
After a sharp contest, the enemy was routed and driven back through Holly Springs, which Confederates occupied.
Our loss was four killed, several wounded.
Yankee loss seven (?)

div3.p:
Arkansas intelligence confirms the report of Curtis's (Federal) being hard pressed by Generals Hind man and Rains.
His capture is considered certain.
Porter's Rangers attacked a guarded wagon train 12 miles east of Memphis, on Tuesday, and destroyed 21 wagons and captured 89 horses and mules.

div3.head: Affairs in Memphis.
div3.p: --The Memphis Argus and Avalanche had both been suppressed — the former for asking Grant's permission to publish the Southern account of McClellan's defeat at Richmond, the latter for alleged incendiary sentiments published in their paper.

The Confederate pickets are now within four miles of Memphis.
Warm work is expected.
Seventeen more of the enemy's pickets were found dead last Wednesday morning.
The Northern papers, of the 30th ult., are perfectly silent on McClellan's "On to Richmond." Young Napoleon's defeat is not mentioned in any Yankee paper.

A dispatch from Cairo states that two companies of Illinois cavalry, whilst going up the river from Memphis, mutinied and took possession of the steam boat.
The cause is not assigned.
They were arrested on their arrival at Cairo.

div3.head: The War in the Southwest.
div3.p: --A special dispatch to the Advertiser, dated Knoxville, 4th, says:

cit.q:
Buell's forces, estimated at 30,000 strong, have all crossed the Tennessee.
It is supposed that they may make a feint movement on Chattanooga to cover movements, by the way of North Alabama, on Rome, Ga. Foraging parties of the enemy are reported to have reached Will's Valley, above Shell Mound.
The Federal forces, under Gen. Morgan, still hold Cumberland Gap.
A sharp cavalry skirmish occurred at Clineh's Valley, Wednesday last.
Several of the enemy are reported killed.
Our loss was two wounded.

div3.head: Bombardment of Vicksburg.
div3.p: --The bombardment continues slowly, with but little effect on either side.

div3.p: (Late Franklin Hall,)
One door below the Exchange Hotel.

div3.head: Thirty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--The above reward is offered for the apprehension and delivery to me of Alexander Trax, a private in my company of light artillery.
He is a German by birth; 38 years of age; 5 feet 5 inches high; stoutly built; dark complexion, and has a peculiarly hoarse voice.
He is supposed to be loitering around Richmond, which was his place of residence previous to his enlistment.
He absented himself from camp about a week ago. John A. Coke,
Captain Williamsburg Artillery.
Artillery Camp, at Blakey's Mill, Near Richmond, July 5, 1862. jy 7--5t*

Private N. P. Green, of Parker's Battery, having deserted, the reward authorized by law, ($30) will be paid for his arrest and delivery to me at Camp Stuart, four miles from Richmond.
Said Green is 26 years old, about 5 feet 8 inches high, light hair and eyes, and by profession a stone-cutter.
div3.closer:
By order of Capt. W. W. Parker.
jy 7--3t*

div3.head: Valuable farm, containing 640 Acres, in Mecklenburg county, one mile from Randolph Macon College, and one Quarter of a mile from Boydton, the county seat.
div3.p:
--We are authorized to sell the farm above described, in Mecklenburg county, containing 640 acres; 250 of which are in original forest, and well timbered.
The remainder is well adapted to the culture of tobacco, and especially grain.
The entire tract is well watered.
Creek and branch bottoms of very superior quality.
The Dwelling is commodious and well arranged in its design for convenience and comfort; it has 9 rooms above basement, large and airy.
The location is exceedingly healthy, and the neighborhood, for intelligence and refinement, unsurpassed.
For terms, &c., apply to
Jas. M. Taylor & son,
jy 7--1w Auct'rs.

Seven hundred Acres land for Sale in Orange county, N. C., first-rate improvements, good water, and well adapted to grass, clover, grain, and tobacco; in two miles of a large woolen factory and flouring mill.
Address me at this office.
[jy 7--7t*] J. P. Bagby.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --I can be found at the corner of 6th and Broad streets, from 8 till 10 o'clock A. M. and at my residence, on Jackson street, third door from Adams, from 3 P. M. till night.
jy 7--3t* A. D. Turner.

div4.p: Departed this life, on Sunday, the 6th of July, 1862, of wounds received in battle on 27th June, Lieut. Col. Bradfute Warwick, of the 4th Texas regiment, son of Corbin Warwick Esq., of this city.
The funeral services of deceased will take place at St. Paul's Church, on Monday, the 7th July, at 5 o'clock P. M. The friends of the family are invited to attend.
On the 6th of July 1862, John T. West infant son of John T. and Catherine West.
The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral this morning at 9 o'clock, from the residence of his parents, on Byrd street, between 9th and 10th.

On the 3d inst., at the residence of his uncle, Rev. H. S. Kepler, of this city, J. Clayton Chamblin, in the 19th year of his age, son of Wm. Jas. H. Chamblin, of Leesburg, and late private Secretary of Maj. Gen. D.H. Hill.

At the residence of Jno. M. Blakey, on 20th st., on Thursday evening, July 3d, of wounds received in the battle of Tuesday, July 1st, while gallantly leading his regiment, Col. T. J. Warthen, of the 28th Georgia Regiment.
At the residence of Mr. H. W. Tyler, on the 5th inst., at 5½ A. M., of typhoid fever, Colonel P. W. Roberts, 14th regiment N. C. volunteers.
Instantly, on the field of battle, on the evening of the 27th ult., Lieut. D. M. Keeler, in the 22d or 23d year of his age.
On the 4th instant, of wounds received in the battle of the 1st, Julian C. Levy, of Company E, 3d Alabama Regiment.
Mobile papers please copy.

div4.head: Obituaries.

lg.l: "A song for the death day of the brave,
For him that went to a hero's grave,

div4.p: Captain Matthew Lyle, of Company K, 18th Regiment Virginia Volunteers, fell, shot through the head while gallantly leading his men to the charge against the enemy in the battle of Gaines's Mill, on Friday evening, the 27th June last.

The writer of this tribute to his memory has known him from his childhood, and can therefore speak confidently of his many virtues.
Gallant and daring to a fault, a faithful friend, a dutiful and affectionate son, a loving and devoted brother.
He has left a vacant place in many hearts that will long hold him in grateful remembrance.
The standard bearer of his regiment having fallen, he took up the colors, and waving them above his head, called on the men to follow — when he fell.

It is said that his sorrowing comrades going to the commanding General, to allow them to bear off his body, were told that no place was so fit for a soldier's grave, as the field he had won by his valor, so they wrapped him in his blanket and buried him where he fell.

lg.l: Nor in sheet or shroud they bound him,
But he lay like a warrior taking his rest,
With his martial cloak around him."
"Slowly and sadly they laid him down,
From the field of his fame fresh and gory;
They carved not a line, they raised not a stone,
But they left him alone in his glory."

div4.p: Charlotte C. H. Va., 1862. H.
Killed, in the battle of Tuesday, July 1st Charles W. Rushbrook, a member of company I, (Elliott Grays,) Capt. Louis F. Bossieux, 6th regiment Virginia volunteers, aged 18 years.

Poor Charlie was instantly killed soon after reaching the field, and whilst in the act of indulging in some playful remark to one of his companions.
His promptness in responding to the call of his officers was the admiration of all; and when we were ordered to the charge his countenance showed with what spirit his youthful heart had entered the bloody field.
Death had marked him for its victim, and he fell in the midst of his comrades, who looked upon his placid and smiling countenance in death with feelings known only to a soldier at the close of a day of battle.

Farewell, Charlie; we shall ever miss thee at roll call.
Your companions have lost a friend who can never be replaced; our country has lost another gallant defender, and a gray haired sire will miss the occupant of the chair of his youngest son. In another and better world we shall meet, where the sorrows and ills of this life will be but a shadow.

div3.head: Wanted — a Gardener.
div3.p:
--I wish to employ a competent Gardener, to take charge of a market farm three or four miles from Richmond.
A steady and industrious man can hear of a situation by addressing "Farmer," Manchester, Va., stating where an interview may be had.

div3.head: Wanted — Dress Makers.
div3.p:
--Two or three good hands can find steady employment, and the highest wages paid — say from $6 to $18 per week.
Apply to day, at Mrs. Rees S, 209 Main street.
jy 7--2t* between 9th and 10th.

Address "G. W. S.," Richmond Post Office.

--A Servant Woman, of good character, who can do ordinary cooking and washing for a small family, by the month, or for the balance of the year.
Any one having such servant, can find a good home for her by addressing "T. T.," at this office.

div3.head: Wanted — to hire.
div3.p:
--By the month, a Servant to attend to my horse, and wait on me in camp.
Apply to Ellett & Drewry, or to myself, at camp near Drury's Bluff.
jy 7--3t* G. W. Ross, Maj. Ga. Bat.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --A Tanner, Apply at once to J. D. Brown & Co., Staunton, Va.
jy 7--12t* J. D. Brown & Co.

div3.head: Wanted — Board.
div3.p:
--By a lady, in a genteel family or private boardinghouse.
Apply to "lady," Dispatch office.
jy 7--3t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--To purchase, a first rate Cow, with young calf.
For which a liberal price will be paid.
Apply to G. M. Lumpkin & Bro., Franklin street, opposite Metropolitan Hall, or address "Box 410," Richmond Post Office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Recruits for the Purcell Battery.--Fifty good men are wanted to fill up vacancies recently created in this company.
For further information, apply at camp, near the Old Fair Grounds. W. J. Pegram,
jy 5--10t* Captain Purcell Battery.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--At the Beauregard House, 17th street, opposite the Market, two first class Dining Room Servants, and a Second Cook, by the month or for the balance of the year.
Apply immediately.
jy 5--3t* Jno. McPHERSON.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A good Cook, and Washer and Ironer.
Also, a Girl, 12 or 14 years old. Any person having such for hire, will find a good home for them by leaving a note for me at the Dispatch office, stating when they may be seen.
jy 5--3t* J. M. Haines.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--At the Danville Woolen Factory, Danville, Va., eight good male Weavers.
If any such apply immediately, very liberal wages will be paid.
jy 5--3t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Board, in a private family, for a young man and his wife — Church Hill (or its neighborhood) preferred.
Address immediately, "R. W. J.," Box 961, Richmond Post-Office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p: --Immediately, 8 or 10 Servants, male or female, at Georgia Hospitals.--Apply to J. T. Newberry, Agt.,
jy 5--4t* corner 21st and Cary streets.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--Room and Board, for a young man, in a private and respectable family, situated near the Capitol Square.
State price.
Address "W. H. R.," Dispatch office.
jy 5 --2t*

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--By a gentleman and his wife, a Room and Board.
A location on Church Hill preferred.
Address "Physician," Dispatch office.
jy 5 --3t*

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p: --Ranaway from the subscriber, June 27, near Richmond, my negro boy Pendleton, about 19 or 20 years old; five feet six or seven inches high; very black; dressed rather military.
A. H. Rogers, A. D. C.
jy 7--6t* Maj. Gen. D. H. Hill.

div3.head: Ranaway
div3.p: --$50 reward.--Ran away from the subscriber, on the 15th of June, a negro man, Lewis. Said negro is about 21 years old five feet six or seven inches high, very black, and stout; had on when he left a black frock coat and military cap. I will give the above reward if delivered to me in Lynchburg; or $30 if secured so I can get him. James Morgan.
Lynchburg, July 1. jy 4--eodlm

div3.head:
Office Chief Quarterm'r, army of Northern Virginia,
corner Bank and 10th sts., Richmond, Va.
div3.p:
It being represented that teamsters are committing depredations on the farms adjacent to Richmond, citizens are requested to find out the names of the teamsters, the regiment to which they belong, and the wagon master in charge of the teams.
If a report, properly substantiated is made to me, the person or persons offending will be punished.

It is my desire to put a stop to these depredations, and it can only be done in the manner above prescribed.
Jas. L. Corley,
jy 4--1w Lieut. Col. and Chief Quarterm'r.

div3.head: Dissolution of Co-Partnership.
div3.p: --The co-partnership heretofore existing between the late firm of D. & P. Epstein, has this day dissolved by mutual consent.
David Epstein,
Philip Epstein,
Richmond, July 5, 1862.

Philip Epstein will continue the Jewelry business on Main street, next door below the Dispatch office; and David Epstein will continue the Clothing business at No. 66 Main street, corner of Locust Alley.
They return their thanks to the public for the liberal patronage heretofore bestowed upon them, and respectfully solicit a continuance of the same to the two houses.

div3.head: Acard.
div3.p:
--In the Richmond Dispatch, of June 21st, my name appears in a list of reported deserters from the 18th Va. Regiment.
To return this charge, ½ will simply place the acts in the case before the public.
At the commencement of hostilities between this Government and the United States I volunteered my services in the Danville lines, for the form of twelve months, which I have served faithfully.
At its expiration, I fell that the condition of my family demanded my attention at home, and concluded to accept the privilege of employing a substitute, which the conscript law afforded me. I left in my place a non-resident of the Confederate States, who had been recommended by the Surgeon of the 18th Va. Regiment and received by the Captain of the company to which I belonged.
I received my discharge, according to law and the orders issued from the War Department.
jy 7--1t* W. P. Smith.

Messrs: Editors: My attention having been called, a few days ago, to an advertisement in the Lynchburg Republican, where I am published as a deserter from company K, 2d Reg't Va. Cavalry, and as this was doubtless done through a mistake, I take this opportunity of requesting the Republican to correct the mistake, as an act of justice to myself and for the information of my friends.
jy 7--3t* Wm. H. Burnley.

div3.head: Special Notice.
div3.p:
--All person having sick or wounded soldiers in their houses, are requested to report their names and the No. of their Regiments to the "Army Intelligence Office," at the Bank of Virginia.
This is very important, in order to enable strangers to find their sick or wounded friends.
jy 7--1t*

div3.head: A lost wounded soldier.
div3.p:
--My son, William T. Miller, of the 60th Virginia regiment, who was wounded and lost one leg in the fight of last week, near Richmond, cannot be found.
Any information lodged at this office, or to his anxious father, at the Cariton House, will be thankfully received.
[jy 7 --1t*] Grief Miller.

Anybody knowing anything about Wm. A. Tuggle, of Company F, 18th Reg't Va. Vols., who was wounded in last Monday's battle, will please leave notice of it at this office, or at the Army, Intelligence Office. C. O. Pape.
jy 7--3t

div3.head: Information wanted
div3.p:
--Of D. D. May and F. G. Colbert, of Co. G, 6th Regt. Ga. Vols., who were wounded in the battle on the 27th June, and were sent to Richmond.
Any information as to where they are will be thankfully received and liberally rewarded.
Address me through the Post Office, or at the Linwood House.
jy 7--2t* Jas. T. may.

div3.head: Information wanted
div3.p: --Of James W. Smith, Co. A, 18th Ga. Regt., who is said to have been wounded in the battle on Friday, 27th June. Any person knowing of his whereabouts will confer a favor on his brother by addressing a few lines through the Richmond Post-Office.
jy 7--2t* Geo. A. Smith.

div3.head: Information wanted
div3.p: --Of the whereabouts of my son, Wm. T. Cowan, who was wounded in the battle of Friday, the 27th ult. Address the undersigned, at the Dispatch office.
jy 7--1t* John Cowan.

div3.head: Information wanted
div3.p:
--Of the whereabouts of Lieut. J. W. Stott, 8th Alabama regiment, who is supposed to be wounded, and in some hospital or private house in the city.
Address.
Serg't D. Buell, at 2d Ala. Hospital,
jy 7--2t* Corner 25th and Franklin sts.

div3.head: Information wanted
div3.p: --Of Orderly Serg't Wm. Matthews, of Co. C, 56th Va. Vols., who was wounded in the battle of the 27th June. Any information of his whereabouts will be thankfully received by his brother at this office.
jy 7--3t* D. C. Matthews.

div3.head: Information wanted
div3.p: --Of the whereabouts of John G. Burk, of Capt. John Duff's company, 37th Regiment Va. Volunteers, by his mother, at the Howard House, 6th street, between Marshall and Clay. jy 7 --3t*

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--To know the whereabouts of Capt. Wm. S. Grady, of Athens, Ga., who is in this city sick.
Any information left at this office will be thankfully received by his friend,
jy 7--1t* J. B. Carlton.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --To know the whereabouts of E. M. Cooper, company E, 4th regiment S. C. volunteers. Address S. Cooper,
jy 7--1t* Dispatch office.
Will Sergeant Mercer Slaughter, of Jones Battalion, Pendleton's reserve, if in the city, send his address to the Drug Store of Meade & Baker, Main street? jy 7--2t*

div3.head: Information wanted.
div3.p: --Sergeant Major A. F. Hill, 4th Georgia regiment, can find James a Hill by inquiring for a letter at the American Hotel, jy 7--2t*

div3.head: Information wanted
div3.p:
--Of Captain R. R. Applewhite, Company H. 12th Mississippi Regiment, Featherstone's Brigade.
He was missed during the fight on Friday evening, the 27th of June, and has not been heard from since.
Any information of his whereabouts would be thankfully received at Chimborazo Hospital, 5th division, ward R. by B. L. Applewhite.
jy 5--3t* Co. H., 12th Miss. Reg't.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Information of Jno. S. Smith, private of Company 1, 1st regiment N. C. troops, Capt. Foote, who was wounded in the forehead at Mechanicsville, and thought to be mortal.
He was sent to the Central Depot on Friday evening, after the fight, still alive.
I suppose he could be identified only by papers in his pockets.
Any information concerning him would be thankfully received.
I am at the Spotswood Hotel, No. 36.
jy 5--3t* H. C. Ligon.

div3.head: Information wanted
div3.p:
--Of Chastain Brown, Company C, 9th Virginia volunteers, who was wounded in one of the recent battles near Richmond.
Any information of his whereabouts will be thankfully received by his brother, at this office.
W. A. Brown.
jy 5--1w Henrico Artillery.

div3.head: Information wanted
div3.p:
--Of Thomas T. Williams, of Company H, Capt. Owens, 12th Virginia regiment, Norfolk Junior Volunteers, who was sent to town about two weeks ago sick.
Information left at the Banner Hospital will be thank fully received, by
jy 5--2t* J. B. Doughty.

div3.head: Personal.
div3.p: --Sergeant G. W. Cummings, Company C, 3d Virginia regiment, was reported badly wounded on the 30th ult. Any information in regard to him will be thankfully received by A. S. Shafer,
jy 5--3t* 110 Main street.

div3.head: Information wanted
div3.p:
--About my son, David M. Thally, a private in the 10th Georgia regiment, Company E.
Any information will be thankfully received at this office by a parent.
If crippled or dead, I wish the body.
Leave information at N. B. Hill's hospital, (tobacco factory,) 21st street, between Cary and Main.
jy 5--3t* David Thally.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Information wanted of the whereabouts of Julian C. Levy, Company E. 3d Alabama regiment.
Wounded in the battle of Tuesday.
Leave address at this office.
By his brother, [jy 5 --3t*] T. B. Levy.

div3.head: Information wanted
div3.p:
--Of A Roebuck and Reuben Carmichael, of Company B, 10th Alabama Regiment.
The former was wounded last Friday, and the latter last Tuesday.
Any information concerning them will be thankfully received by their officers at the Dispatch office.
Capt. W. K Gore, 18th Regiment N. C. State Troops, will please give his situation to Maj. W. S. Ash, as there are various friends making inquiry for him. jy 5--2t*

div3.head: Lock Weems.
div3.p: --Any one who can inform me where I can find Capt. Lock Weems, of the 15th Alabama Regiment, who was wounded in a late engagement, will confer a great favor by addressing me a note through the Post-Office.
jy 5--3t* A. H. Shepherd.

div3.head: Information wanted
div3.p:
--Of I. A. F. Cannon, a member of company G, 28th Georgia Regiment, now on sick list in this city or neighborhood.
A note addressed to his father, Richmond Post-Office, will be thankfully received.
jy 5--3t* John F. cannon.

John M. Stone, of Capt. Jennings's company, 38th Virginia regiment, was wounded on the 21st of June in both arms.
Any information of his whereabouts, left with J. A. Collins, Bank of the Commonwealth, will be most gratefully received by his father.
jy 5--3t* Joseph M. Stone.

div3.head: Personal.
div3.p: --Will Mrs. Pope, wife of a member of the Richmond Howitzers, give Allen Davis her address through the Dispatch.

div3.head: Personal.
div3.p:
--H. A. Taylor is at the Clifton House.
jy 5--2t*

My brother, Randolph Bacon, is in town, wounded, and I am very anxious to know where he is. He is a member of the Butler Guards, 2d South Carolina Regt. Any one knowing of his whereabouts will please send me word at Mr. Mear's corner of 4th and Canal streets, Richmond.

Also,--O. Holzendore is sick in town, and will report where he is to the same place.
He is of the 3d Georgia Regt.
jy 4--2t* G. Washington Hicks,

If Lieut. R. E. Calder, Co. B, 2d N. C. T., is in any of the hotels or hospitals of this city, he will please write to his brother, at the Columbian Hotel.
Any person cognizant of anything concerning him, will confer a great favor by informing me immediately.
Address
2d N. C. T., No. 29 Columbian Hotel.

div3.head: Information wanted
div3.p: --Of the whereabouts of Lieut. Wynn, 7th Georgia regiment, by his father, at C, Lunisden's 26 Main street.

div3.head: North Carolinians.
div3.p: --I will be glad to hear from any member of companies K and I, 2d and 3d Regiments N. C. State Troops, and can be found at R. Lumpkin's Hotel, Richmond.
jy 4--3t* B. A. Shipp.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The sick and wounded of the 5th Texas regiment will please send their address to A. H. Edey, Agent of the regiment, corner of Cary and Virginia streets.
jy 3--6t*

div3.head: Information wanted.
div3.p:
--Of the house or hospital where Lieut. F. C. Robbins is, and also J. L. Robbins, who were both wounded Friday.
They belong to Company C. 4th Alabama regiment.
Tell them Capt. Robbins and M. C.

div3.head: Estray.
div3.p: --A small gray Horse, with a sore on his back, was brought to the office of Assistant Provost Marshal Alexander, on the 30th of May last, and placed by him in the livery stable of James C. Johnson, corner of 15th and Franklin streets. If the owner does not appear by Saturday, the 12th of July, 1862,and pay charges for the keeping of said horse, he will be sold at public auction, and the money, after deducting said charges, will be put in the hands of Capt. Alexander, A. P. M., to be paid over to the owner whenever called for. Jas. C. Johnson.
jy 7--3t

div3.head: Twenty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Was taken from the door of Mr. H. W. Tyler's Commission store, on Thursday, the 3d of July, a light chesnut sorrel Horse, with the left hind leg white up to the knee; white star in the forehead, and a scar on the rump, caused from a bite; he had on a bridle, saddle, halter, and martingale.
I will give the above reward for his return to me, in Port Mayo, below Rocketts, or for any information that may lead to his recovery.
John McDOWELL.

div3.head: Twenty-five dollars reward
div3.p:
--For my gray Mare, taken from the Exchange Hotel alley, last Friday morning. She is a pretty animal, dark mane and tail; shoulders slightly blistered with collar; fore shoes steel tipped.
She had on a fine black stitched saddle, and single bridle with curb bit. She has two small wens on her back under the saddle.
The above reward will be given to any one who will bring her to.
Dr. J. B. McCAW, 5th street,
jy 7--3t* between Grace and Franklin.

div3.head: Lost--$20 reward.
div3.p:
--Lost on the 3d of July, on the railroad, between the Fair Grounds and Brook Run, a Porte-Monnaie, containing about Eighty dollars--one $50, one $20 and a $5 Confederate notes; one $2 North Carolina note, two $1 notes and one dollar in City Scrip.--There was also a dose of calomel from L. Wagner in the book.
The above reward will be paid by leaving it at M. W. Swain's, corner 6th and Marshall streets, for at this office.
jy 7--3t*

div3.head: Lost--$10 reward.
div3.p:
--Lost, on the battle field, near Gaines's Mill, an Army five Shooter.
My name is engraved on the plate.
The above reward will be paid for its delivery to me at camp near Blakey's Mill, or at my residence, on Marshall street, between 2d and 3d, in this city.
S. H. Pendleton,
jy 7--3t* Lieut. Williamsburg Artillery.

div3.head: Lost.
div3.p:
--Certificates of the Commercial Savings Bank at Richmond, Va., as follows: No. 2766, to B. W. Moseley for $229, dated 3d February, 1862, No. 2770, to B. W. Moseley for $187.68, dated 7th February, 1862. The above having been lost or mislaid, application will be made to the Bank for duplicates.
B. W. Moseley.
jy 7--2aw3w

div3.head: Ten dollars reward for my Horse.
div3.p:
--He was rode off by some soldier on the 1st day of July. He is a bay, with a little hair rubbed off his tail, and is a wind or crib sucker.
Has marks on both hind feet from being cut by a rope.
John W. Newton,
jy 7--3t* Stony Run Hill, New Bridge Road.

div3.head: Stray Mare.
div3.p:
--Came to my house, head of Brook Turnpike, on the 20th ultimo, a light bay Mare.
The owner can get her by calling on me, proving property and paying charges.
Richard M. Turner,
Head of Brook Turnpike,
jy 7--3t* 6 miles from Richmond.

div3.head: Lost
div3.p:
--Near the corner of 9th and Broad sts., a large Iron Key. The finder will confer a great favor by leaving it at Capt. Wm. E. Warner's office, Bank street, 4th door below 9th, or at this office.
[jy 7--1t*] S. S. Carter.

div3.head: Strayed
div3.p:
--From Chaffin's Bluff, on the morning of July 1st, a small black Mare; lame in the right hind ankle.
She had on a cloth halter.
I will give $10 reward for her delivery to me at Chaffin's Bluff, or at Old Fair Grounds.
Ira. W. Alley,
jy 7--3t* Capt. Wren's Co.

div3.head: Taken up
div3.p:
--On the farm of the late Judge Peter V. Daniel, about a mile from the city, two black Mules, and an old sorrel Horse, which the owner can have by paying the expense of this advertisement.
jy 7--3t*

div3.head: Lost
div3.p:
--A small Pocket-Book, containing money, papers, &c. It was left at the Fredericksburg Railroad ticket office.
The finder will be liberally rewarded by leaving it with the Ticket Agent of the R. & F. R. R.
jy 7--2t* Samuel H. Bell.

div3.head: Twenty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay the above reward for the return of a dark bay Horse, the property of Capt. Warner, C. S. Prison, that escaped from my office, in front of the Shockoe Warehouse, on Saturday last.
He is of medium size, drooped rump, has several saddle marks, a very small white spot on his left hind ankle, and a small fresh scar on his right; paces finely.
Had on when he left a black Mexican saddle, very high in front and behind, padded beneath.
He has, I presume, been taken up by some one, who is anxious to return him, which he will please do at my residence, on Cary, between 2d and 3d streets, and receive the above reward.
jy 5--3t* Thos. Tinsley Johnson.

div3.head: Lost Horse.
div3.p:
--Turned out of the Capitol Square, at a late hour on Friday night last, by the guard, a Horse, supposed to have been improperly put there.
The Horse is a dark roan, 10 or 11 years old; the fore top cut short; is a good draft Horse, and shoulders showing marks of the collar, &c. A reward of $5 will be paid to any person who will deliver said horse to the subscriber, at the Carlton House, on 12th, between Broad and Marshall streets.
jy 5--2t* F. W. Bass, Dep. Marshal.

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed or stolen, on Sunday, June 29, from Gen. Lee's headquarters, at Dabb's house, on the Nine-Mile road, about a mile from the city limits, a handsome bay Mare, about 15½ hands high, six years old, with a cut on the back of the right fore leg, a little above the fetlock, which made her slightly lame.--The above reward will be paid for her return to Dabb's house, or the Staff stables on Grace street, opposite the Capitol Square, or for such information as will enable the owner to recover her. The in formation to be left at Dabb's house.
jy 5--6t*

div3.head: Lost.
div3.p:
--On Tuesday, the 1st July, near the battle field, thirteen miles from Richmond, chesnut sorrel Stallion, with the left eye out, in thin order, having a long, fine mane, and about 15½ hands high.
Any person giving information of the same to Capt. Heath, Commissary 20th Georgia regiment, will be suitably rewarded.
John A. Jones.
jy 5--4t* Lt. Col. 20th Georgia Regt.

div3.head: Strayed or stolen.
div3.p: --From the corner of 7th and Franklin streets, July 3d, a small sorrel Horse, aged 8 or 9 years, white marks on the lower part of face, mane and tail light colored; has a sore back, and had on an army saddle, with common holster pistols and a gum coat in front, I will pay twenty dollars reward for the delivery of the horse and saddle to Mr. Woodson, upper part of Broad street; for the horse I will pay $10.
Corp'l B. F. Ford, H. L. Dragoons,
jy 5--2t* 10th Reg't Va. Cavalry.

div3.head: Lost Trunk.
div3.p:
--Was given to a negro boy to carry to 18th street, a Trunk, covered with oil cloth, painted black, the bands painted green.
It contained nothing but ladies' apparel.
A liberal reward will be paid for the recovery of the same, and any information concerning it will be thank fully received, if left at Mr. John Dooley's Hat Store, Main street.
jy 5--2t* Annie E. Farmer.

div3.head: Lost.
div3.p:
--On the battle field — Poindexter's farm-- on Tuesday, 2d instant, a sorrel Horse.
He is raw bone; navel galley; has both hind feet white; had on when lost a military saddle and halter bridle.
A liberal reward will be paid on bringing him to Ellett & Drewry's 17 Pearl street.
jy 5--2t* 1st Co. Richmond Howitzers.

div3.head: Lost.
div3.p:
--In this city, on the 3d inst., a medium sized black Satchel, filled with some refreshment and some valuable Clothing.
I think it went off in an army wagon, and I got a small Satchel in exchange.
Any person finding mine will please leave it at the Dispatch office, where the exchange can be made.
R. L. Holmes.

div3.head: Lost.
div3.p:
--From the platform of the Virginia Central Railroad, at Gordonsville, on Monday, June 30 a Black Traveling bag, tied with rope and tacked.
It contained wearing apparel.
A liberal reward will be paid for its recovery.
jy 5--3t* Hugh Latham, Richmond.

div3.head: Estrayed.
div3.p:
--Came to my farm, in Chesterfield county, on the 3d inst., a red-spotted Steer, and white and red Heifer; both in very good order.
The owner will come forward, prove property, pay charges, and take them away.
jy 5--3t* A. F. Jahnke.

div3.head: Ten dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed from his house, yesterday, a little Pet Dog, named Bijou.
He has white curly hair, with light brown ears--one ear hangs down, while the other stands up; has black eyes and nose.
The little dog is the gift of a valued friend, and belongs to a lady, second house, corner of 1st and Grace streets, south side.
jy 5--3t*

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Taken from the door of the Spotswood Hotel, on the evening of June 23d, one dark, iron gray Mare, black mane and tail, sixteen hands high, nine years old, defective eyes, and branded on the left shoulder with the letters C. S. Also, a military black saddle, with brass mountings, and one double rein, russet bridle, steel bit. Information to be left at the Dispatch office.
jy 5--3t*

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--On Sunday afternoon last, my servant Martha left my house on a visit, and has not since returned.
Supposing she has been taken by the Provost Guard, I shall be pleased to have her returned immediately, as she is the only servant employed in my family.
D. W. Hughes.
Corner of 17th and Franklin streets,
jy 5--2t* Over A. B. Clarke's store.

div3.head: Found.
div3.p:
--Found, a Pocket Book, containing a large amount of money, which the owner can have by describing the same.
Apply to Wm. W. Davies,
At John W. Davies's Marble Works.

div3.head: Strayed Oxen.
div3.p: --Came to "Broad Rock," on 1st July three Oxen, which the owner is requested to call for, pay charges and take away.
D. McDANIEL,
jy 5--3t* Chesterfield county.

div3.head: Lost.
div3.p:
--A Gold Watch, single case, No. 2,227, thirteen jewels.
The under will receive $25 by applying at this office.

div3.head: By R. Cauthorn, Auctioneer.
div3.p: Bacon, Beef, &c. At Auction.--On Monday, 7th inst, at 10 o'clock, at my store, I will sell at auction, on account of whom it may concern, 75 Bacon Hams, 45 Bacon Sides, and 100 bbls, 11 boxes and 4 bbls Pickled Beef, and 170 pieces Smoked Beef.
Tobacco, Cigars, ground Coffee, Soda, Starch, Spice, Cloves.

After the above, I will sell 10 boxes Tobacco, part bright and nice; 22,000 Cigars, 5 boxes Ground Coffee, Soda, Starch, 4 bags Allspice.
I bag Cloves, 18 iron bound Stands, suitable for liquor; Ginger, empty Barrels, 2 Writing Desks, Corks, &c.,
jy 5 R. Cauthorn, Auct.

div2.head:
Future days.
by Redwood & Keach, Aucts, [54 Main street.]

div3.p: New and Second Hand Furniture.--
400 pair Wood Shoes, assorted;
200 lbs. Shoe Thread;
300 lbs. Bacon Sides;
A large assortment of Crockery and Glassware;
2 large Show-Cases and Counters;
2 Sewing Machines;
Dry Goods, Clothing, &c.,
At auction, on Tuesday, July 8th, commencing at 10 o'clock, at store.
Redwood & Keach,
jy 7--1ds Auctioneers.

div3.head:
By Thos. W. Keesee.
Auctioneer,
[office corner of 12th and Cary streets.]
div3.p:
Closing out Sale of Earthenware and Glass at Auction.--On Tuesday next, the 8th instant, we shall offer at auction the balance of our stock of Earthenware and Glass.
We invite the special attention of dealers, merchants, and others, to the goods to be sold.
There are many large as well as small lots of goods, and as this will be positively our final sale, all those in want of goods, would do well to attend, as every lot offered will be sold without limit or reserve.
Geo. J. Sumner &Co., Gov. st.
Sale conducted by Thos. W. Keesee, Auct'r.
jy 7--2t

div3.head:

[Wilmington N. C.]
div3.p: Auction Sale.--The Valuable Cargo of the steamship "Modern Greece," from London, arrived at Confederate Point, will be sold on Tuesday, 8th inst., at Wilmington, comprising a general assortment, by
Wilkes Morris, Auct'r.
Thos. B. Power, Consignee. jy 5--3t*

div3.head:
[Extract.]
Adj't and Insp'r General's office,
Richmond, July 4th, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders, No. 154.--

II.
Conscripts engaged on Government work, either directly or by contractors, will not be taken from the work on which they were engaged, except for the purpose of enrollment, after which they will be returned on the certificate of the officer under whose charge the work is being performed, or with whom the contract is made.
Such certificate will be presented, to the enrolling officer, who will thereupon order the detail of the men specified for a period not to exceed sixty days. A duplicate of each detail will be forwarded at once to the Adjutant and Inspector General; and a triplicate for the Department or Bureau for which the work is performed.
Extensions of these details will be made when deemed necessary on application through the Heads of Departments or Bureaus.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War. Jno. Withers,
jy 5--2w Ass't Adj't General.

div3.head: War Department, Adjutant and Insp'r Gen's office, Richmond, July 4, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 47.
I. The reception of unnaturalized foreigners as Substitutes in the army is hereby forbidden.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War. (Signed) S. Cooper.
jy 5--1w Adj't and Insp'r General.

head.hi: Headq's 3d brigade Huger's Div's, camp near Melvin Hill,

div3.p: Special Orders, No.--

All officers, non-commissioned officers, and privates of this command who are absent from their companies and regiments, are required to return to duty immediately, or they will be published in the Richmond and Georgia papers as deserters.
Those who are really sick will send to these headquarters a surgeon's certificate of their condition.
No brave officer or private will skulk from duty in such a time as this.
Cowards alone hug the city or wagon camps when their comrades are gallantly confronting the insolent foe and driving him from our soil.
div3.closer:
By order of Brig. Gen. Wright.
V. J. B. Girardy.
jy 5--3t* A. A. General

div3.head: To members of 8th Georgia Reg't Richmond.
div3.p:
--All members of the regiment in this city without authority are requested immediately to return to camp.
In this great exigency no private or officer of the 8th Georgia should leave his colors without the severest necessity, and will be expected in all cases to have complete official authority for doing so. Being confined to my bed and not in command, I can only appeal to the patriotism of my men, and desire every one not severely ill or wounded to stand last by the regimental colors.
div3.closer:
Lucius M. Lamar
jy 5--2t* Col. of 8th Reg't Ga. Vos.

div3.p: To the sick and wounded soldiers from Alabama, now in private Residences, Boarding Houses, or Hotels, the undersigned offer their services one may always be found at the office of Maj. Vandevier, Alabama Depot, on Main st. above 9th

div3.p:
Second Lieut. James Garrity, Company E. 5th La. Reg't is badly wounded and any member of his company seeing this advertisement will please call and see him, at "Chimborazo Hospital," Church Hill, Div. No.
"I," Ward H. No. 12.
jy 5--t.

--Elliott's, Battalions for City Defence.
Pay, $31 per month and applications.
To be stationed in city barracks.
But a few more men wanted.
Conscripts, second-class militia, soldiers discharged for disability, Kentuckian, Marylander, in fact all persons not now in service, will be taken.
Call at once, as we desire to muster in a few days.
Apply at 80 Main street, opposite Morris's Bookstore.

I am authorized by the Governor to raise a regiment of Cavalry, to serve under Major General Floyd.
Persons wishing to get up, or assist in getting up, companies for this regiment, can do so by seeing or writing to me at Richmond.
div3.closer:
J. E. Johnson
(Late Colonel 9th Va. Cavalry,)
je 27--1m* Col. Cavalry, Floyd's Division.

div3.head: Victory or death.
div3.p: --F. La Barre manufacturer of the Beauregard battle Flag Badge, Broad street, between 6th and 7th north side, sign of the Battle Flag.

This badge of metal, highly hammered with the motto "Victory of Death" engraved on it is to be worn on the hat or cap, of a good size, so as to be seen far off, as a distinction from the enemy.
It ought to be adopted by every soldier as a safeguard against mistakes.
Respective regiments and companies can have the number of the regiment and name of State engraved on it, by orders addressed to.
F. La Barre,
jy 5--6t* Box 946, Richmond Va.

head.hi: Office Ga. R. And H. Ass'n,

div3.p: Notice to Georgians.--Georgia soldiers sick or wounded, who may be at private as dences, unable to procure medical attendance, as requested to notify the agent of the Georgia Richmond and Hospital Association, office corner of 21st and Cary streets, (Crew & Pemberton's Factory,) and they will be visited by the medical officer of the Association, recently from Augusta or by leaving word at Room No. 103 Spotswood flood, by DeBillings, from Columbus, Ga.
J. M. Selkirk,

jy 2--2w* Gen'l Agent Ga.
R. and H. Ass't.
